title: Can a General-Purpose AI Autonomously Characterize and Exploit an Unknown Quantum Processor?

phase1_discovery.description: AI started with zero prior knowledge of Tuna-9 topology. Designed and executed probing experiments.

step1_single_qubit.method: X gate + measure on all qubits, then individual qubit isolation

step2_connectivity.method: Bell state probe (H + CNOT) on 20 qubit pairs
step2_connectivity.key_finding: Hardware rejects non-connected CNOT pairs with FAILED status, enabling topology discovery through failure analysis
step2_connectivity.surprise_finding: Previous experiments reported q6-8 had no CNOT connectivity. AI discovered 4 new connections: 3-6, 4-6, 6-8, 7-8. The full processor is connected across all 9 qubits.

step3_noise_characterization.method: Bell state tomography (Z, X, Y basis) on best, medium, and worst connections

connections_probed.label: best
connections_probed.signature: ZZ > XX ≈ |YY| — Z correlations preserved, X/Y degraded

connections_probed.label: worst
connections_probed.signature: Dominated by q0 T1 decay — 10% asymmetric bit-flip

phase2_exploitation.description: AI designed hardware-aware circuit routing based on discovered topology and noise profile
phase2_exploitation.strategy: Route GHZ circuits through best qubits (q2,q4,q5,q6,q8) avoiding worst qubit (q0)

naive.why_bad: Uses q0 (12.3% error) as hub qubit controlling both CNOTs

optimal.why_good: Uses top-3 qubits with best connections (93.5%, 92.3%)

phase3_analysis.headline_result: Hardware-aware routing by AI improves GHZ fidelity by 5.8 percentage points, reducing per-qubit error by 33%
key_findings: AI discovered the full Tuna-9 topology in 20 Bell-pair probes, finding 4 previously unknown connections
Hardware failure signals (FAILED jobs) serve as topology information — no documentation needed
The worst qubit (q0, 12.3% error) creates a 7% T1 decay bottleneck in any circuit using it
Noise characterization revealed dephasing on best connections vs depolarizing on worst
Simple routing optimization (avoiding bad qubits) gives 33% per-qubit error reduction
The improvement is consistent across 3-qubit and 5-qubit circuits (+5.8 pp each)
No error mitigation techniques used — improvement comes purely from qubit selection
limitations: Only tested GHZ-type circuits (entanglement-heavy, not algorithmically diverse)
Tuna-9 topology is small (9 qubits) — larger processors have more routing freedom
Hardware conditions may vary over time (recalibration could change optimal routing)
AI used exhaustive probing — a smarter strategy could reduce characterization overhead
